content.webTitle: Billy Bragg review – Americana with an Essex twang

fields.headline: Billy Bragg review – Americana with an Essex twang
fields.bodyText: The Enmore theatre it ain’t. Billy Bragg has rarely seen a grander stage in the 30-plus years since he hit the road with his collection of abrasive, wise songs about politics, love and points in between. In the splendour of the Sydney Opera House on Sunday night, it was impossible not to reflect on the journey he has made from post-punk proselytiser to master singer-songwriter, carrying the conscience of a couple of generations with a passion undimmed by the decades. But although he will always be seen as an acutely political artist – he is appearing on ABC’s Q&A on Monday night – and his views will guarantee him a platform for as long as he wants one, it is the enduring power of his songwriting that is most remarkable. The opening song, Ideology, sounds fantastically fresh as his band, complete with keyboards and pedal steel, soften the old edges. The band has a distinctly country twang and they carry on in this satisfying vein, showcasing songs such as Chasing Rainbows from his most recent album, Tooth and Nail, which was recorded in the US. Adding to the flavour, he is wearing a western pearl-snap shirt and has grown a beard. Bragg – who would have made a good stand-up comedian if all else had failed – confronts head-on suggestions by some critics that he has somehow gone country, quipping that the facial hair hides “a multitude of chins” and that he’s always had a twang – an Essex twang. But, despite his inherent Englishness, his career has been inspired by American music and he proudly tells us Tooth and Nail put him on the Americana charts for the first time. Bragg’s love of Americana, a sound defined as coming from American roots music, led to a spat with singer Pokey LaFarge because of his claim that British artists started it all. To prove his point, he launches into a cover of the Stones’ magnificent Dead Flowers, a British Americana classic if ever there was one. He doesn’t need to justify himself. Later comes a beautiful version of California Stars, one of the Woody Guthrie songs he put to music for the Mermaid Avenue album with Wilco, while Bragg’s hobo hero would have been proud to call There Will Be A Reckoning his own. Throughout, we’re peppered with Bragg’s standards. Between The Wars and Milkman of Human Kindness are still spine-tingling, while A New England, Kraftwerk-style, is a joy. He closes with the traditional, stirring Waiting for the Great Leap Forwards and even though some of the well-heeled audience look as though they might be dreading, not waiting, for the revolution, it still delights and we leave with spirits recharged.
